Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supramolecular Polycondensation of Polymer Brushes via DNA Hybridization
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Living organisms are very proficient at utilizing nanoscopic objects, such as proteins, as building blocks to create materials that they need. Indeed, protein-protein interactions are the foundation of all cells because they are highly directional, specific, and reversible; these are characteristics that synthetic chemists have yet to fully emulate. The goal of this project is to emulate some of the precision-assembly ability that natural proteins exhibit by extracting the requirements for such assembly, and recreating them in new forms accessible to modern polymer and organic chemistry. Towards this goal, the PI's team will design bottlebrush-like synthetic polymers (where long polymer molecules have short appendages across them like the bristles in a bottlebrush) and connect them with short strands of DNA. Because DNA recognition of a complementary strand is well defined, one can in principle design the interconnectivity of the brush polymers with one another accurately. With this approach, it is possible to create a new class of "superpolymers", i.e. polymers whose building blocks are nanoscale-sized polymeric objects. The PI will explore the kinds of superpolymers that can be formed, and identify rules governing their formation. Because of the specificity of DNA recognition, polymer building blocks with various properties, such as size, electrical conductivity, or biological interactions, can be linked together in a sequence-specific and spatially defined manner, to create functional materials previously difficult or impossible to access. This synthetic technique also has the potential to be mediated by innate nucleic acids in cells, and therefore has important implications in medicine. These research activities will intertwine with educational programs to provide laboratory training to graduate/undergraduate students (including undergraduates from institutions lacking research capabilities) and to promote learning and awareness in science-related careers among high school students and STEM teachers.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Nanoscopic objects such as macromolecules and colloidal nanoparticles can form ordered structures when there exist attractive forces. Because sphere-like particles uniformly interact across their surfaces, directional assembly to form 1D or 2D structures represents a significant challenge. In this project, co-funded by the Polymers and Biomaterials Programs in the Division of Materials Research, the PI will utilize DNA recognition as a functional group-equivalent to program the bottom-up assembly of made-to-order polymeric building blocks that can interact with each other only in defined directions. These limited-valency building blocks will be used to study topologically regulated supramolecular polymerizations. The proposed self-assembly strategy involves the synthesis of triblock brush polymers as "macromonomers", which will be conjugated with nucleic acids. The hybridization between the nucleic acid strands allows the monomers to self-assemble head-to-tail, connecting them either linearly or with branching, to form higher order assemblies. By systematically studying a library of brush polymers with different side-chain length, DNA duplex, and reactive block length, mechanistic insights about linear assembly of the brush building blocks will be obtained. In addition, superpolymer sequence control will be studied using multiple monomer systems (e.g. AA+BB), paving the ground for creating multi-component functional materials. Concepts from polycondensation reactions that define small-molecule polymerization will be tested against superpolymer synthesis, utilizing mono- and multi-valency macromonomers, which are expected to provide control over architecture, average degree of polymerization, and chain-end functionality. The capabilities gained from this project will open a wide spectrum of designer materials whose sequential and topological characteristics are well-defined on the nanoscopic scale, and will bring about new knowledge in polymer science and create opportunities to study yet unknown properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project is based on the idea of mimicking the ability for natural proteins to assemble in a directional, specific, and reversible fashion using synthetic analogues. The approach is to extract the requirements for such assemblies, and recreate them in new forms accessible to modern polymer and organic chemistry. Towards this goal, we designed bottlebrush-like synthetic polymers and connected them with short strands of DNA. Using the DNA’s ability to recognize a complementary sequence, we can direct the brush polymers to connect with one another in a programmable manner. Using this approach, we have created news classes of “suprapolymers”, i.e. polymers whose building blocks are nanoscale polymeric objects, and developed the theoretical underpinnings that govern the manner in which the building blocks are assembled, as well as the structure and size distribution of the product. These efforts required scientific advances in several aspects, spanning new synthetic chemistries, mathematical modeling, biochemical assays, and advanced characterization. By pushing on all of these fronts, we were able to make scientific contributions beyond the originally intended area of study.

At the beginning of the project, we postulated that the DNA-brush polymer conjugates, termed pacDNA, may have important implications in medicine through interaction with innate DNA or RNA in cells. The postulate turns out to be prescience, because the pacDNA exhibited an important trait: its binding with a complementary DNA sequence is not affected by the polymer, but the interaction between the DNA and proteins is significantly reduced. This “selectivity” is crucial for the development of DNA-based drugs, which suffer from many side effects stemming from DNA-protein interactions. By reducing these interactions, the pacDNA promises to be a safer and more effective alternative platform to current DNA drug designs. To date, support from the NSF CAREER Award has resulted in 23 journal publications/book chapters (with three more under review), five non-provisional US or international patent applications (one of which has been granted in 2019), and >70 university seminars/conference presentations. In addition, a startup company was formalized to further develop the pacDNA technology toward medical translation based on the intellectual property portfolio realized with NSF support.

These research activities have been intertwined with educational programs to provide laboratory training to postdoctoral fellows, visiting scholars, graduate/undergraduate students, and high school interns. To date, six PhD students, two MS students, and one postdoctoral fellow have worked on this project, with three PhD students and both MS students receiving their degree based on their work on this project. We have also heavily recruited undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups. To date, we have supervised 42 undergraduate students conducting research, 28 of whom are female, and five are African American. With their contributions, 18 undergraduate students became co-authors on our research papers. We have also participated in the NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program, through which three underrepresented minority students were recruited to conduct research for a ten-week summer project from institutions lacking research capabilities. All three students have subsequently been accepted in chemistry PhD programs (UCLA, UCSB, and UW-Madison). At the high school level, we have collaborated with local high schools to recruit students for a summer internship. This collaboration resulted in eight high school students over the course of five years coming to our laboratory to experience the daily operations of a research, gain hands-on practice, and explore career options in STEM. In addition to recruiting and training students, we have developed a Polymer Chemistry course at Northeastern. It was obvious that there was need for students to be educated in polymer science for both academic and industrial careers, but the need was not reflected in our curriculum. Full-time graduate/upper undergraduate students as well as part-time students ranging from high school teachers to industrial scientists took advantage of the course. In fact, through this course, the PI came to know two of his high school teacher collaborators. A second course, Nucleic Acid Chemistry, is set to be developed for Fall, 2020.
